Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story:
I wiped the sweat from my brow as the foreman called out, “End of shift! Make sure your area’s clean before you go.” My boots crunched over scattered nails and sawdust, and I knew the safety inspector would be by in the morning. As a construction laborer, I was expected to leave the site spotless—no shortcuts, no excuses. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, vibrating with a reminder: “Advocacy meeting in 20 minutes.” As an advocate, punctuality was non-negotiable. Missing a meeting meant letting down clients who counted on me to speak for them, to show up when it mattered.

I glanced at the mess around me, then at the time. If I stayed to clean properly, I’d be late for the meeting. If I left now, the site would be unsafe, and I’d be shirking my responsibility to my crew. My stomach twisted with anxiety. Both roles demanded my full attention, both had people depending on me, and I couldn’t see a way to meet everyone’s expectations at once. I stood frozen, broom in hand, heart pounding, torn between two worlds that refused to overlap.
